nodes.text: The widespread use of constant elasticity of substitution (CES) functions in integrated assessment models (IAMs) for long-term energy technology substitutions creates modeling artifacts that produce unrealistically monotonically and exponentially increasing carbon price trajectories, thus misleading policy analysis

CES functions are share-preserving and imply a marginal rate of technical substitution that depends on the current factor ratio, which mathematically forces exponentially increasing inputs of substitutes as substitution progresses

A stylized CES application substituting fossil energy (F) with renewable energy (R) for constant output yields: (i) exponentially increasing R required to replace F, (ii) saturation far from complete substitution, (iii) carbon price small initially then increasing exponentially, and (iv) strong sensitivity to elasticity parameter
Historical technological and energy transitions follow S-curve diffusion dynamics with increasing elasticity of substitution during diffusion, not the constant elasticity assumed by CES

Major IAMs and hybrid models (examples: GTEM-C, MIT EPPA, GCAM, MERGE, Markal-Macro applications) implement nested CES or CES variants across production and energy sectors and produce rising carbon price trajectories consistent with CES artifacts

Mathematical property: the marginal rate of technical substitution MRTS(R,F) equals -[alpha/(1-alpha)]*(R/F)^(1+rho), leading to decreasing marginal ease of substitution as R share grows when rho positive

Simulation results from the CES example show that with initial fossil share around 85% reducing it to 55% can require multi-fold increases (e.g., 13x) in R and carbon taxes rising by orders of magnitude even for partial substitution

Empirical studies and historical data indicate energy and technology substitutions exhibit logistic, Gompertz, or Bass diffusion patterns with accelerating adoption, cost reductions, and increasing substitutability during deployment

Model outputs from GTEM-C and EPPA display exponentially rising carbon prices (hundreds to thousands USD/tCO2) to achieve modest renewable penetration, matching CES-driven behavior rather than physical or technical constraints

The CES-induced artifact of high, rising carbon prices has three policy implications: price diversion (overreliance on price instruments instead of physical deployment planning), sticker shock (political paralysis due to perceived prohibitive costs), and technological myopia (models favor incumbent technologies already in the share structure)

Because CES formulations treat technologies not initially present as effectively unusable without intervention, IAMs tend to favor technologies included at model specification such as CCS, nuclear, or biomass with CCS irrespective of real-world technical scalability or costs

A practical alternative is to use a dynamically varying elasticity of substitution calibrated to expected diffusion and technical profiles or to adopt physical energy system models that represent energy flows, storage, and technical limits explicitly

Simulations with linearly or exponentially decreasing rho (increasing effective elasticity over time) produce S-curve like substitution and carbon price trajectories bounded by substitute technology costs rather than exponentially rising without bound

Policy recommendation: modelers should replace or modify CES usage for long-term energy transitions by implementing dynamic elasticity or physics-based approaches and complement price instruments with explicit deployment targets and infrastructure planning

Assumption underlying critique: IAMs aim to map climate-economy interactions and derive carbon prices, but when internal production functions misrepresent technical substitutability they produce misleading policy-relevant outputs
